summary: This is the Office of the Inspector General's report on its investigation into the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It details the failures and misconduct by BOP staff that contributed to Epstein being alone and unmonitored in his cell, leading to his suicide on August 10, 2019. The report concludes that while staff engaged in significant policy violations and falsified records, there was no evidence contradicting the FBI's determination that Epstein's death was a suicide. This is the Office of the Inspector General's (OIG) official draft report on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) care, custody, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details eight recommendations for BOP policy changes following Epstein's death, includes the BOP's responses concurring with all recommendations, and provides the OIG's analysis of those responses.

events.title: Epstein's Arrest
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey and transported to MCC New York as a pretrial detainee on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: First Hanging Incident
events.description: Epstein found in his SHU cell with an orange cloth around his neck. His cellmate (Inmate 1) said Epstein tried to hang himself. Epstein was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Psychology Department Cellmate Directive
events.description: The MCC New York Psychology Department sent an email to over 70 staff stating Epstein 'needs to be housed with an appropriate cellmate' following his removal from psychological observation.

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: During a meeting with his attorneys at MCC New York, Epstein signed a new Last Will and Testament. MCC New York officials were unaware until after his death.

events.title: Cellmate Transferred, Epstein Left Alone
events.description: Epstein's cellmate (Inmate 3) was transferred out of MCC New York. No action was taken to assign a new cellmate, leaving Epstein alone in his cell.
personsInvolved: Day Watch SHU Officer in Charge
Evening Watch SHU Officer in Charge

events.title: Unmonitored Phone Call
events.description: A Unit Manager allowed Epstein to make an unrecorded, unmonitored telephone call, allegedly to his mother but actually to Individual 1, in violation of BOP policy.

events.title: Failure to Conduct Counts and Rounds
events.description: SHU staff failed to conduct required inmate counts and 30-minute rounds overnight. Count slips and round sheets were falsified.
personsInvolved: Evening Watch SHU Officer in Charge

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: At approximately 6:30 a.m., SHU staff found Epstein hanged in his locked cell. He was pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 a.m. The Medical Examiner ruled the death a suicide.

events.title: Autopsy Results
events.description: The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, City of New York, performed an autopsy and determined the cause of death was hanging and the manner of death was suicide.

events.title: Noel and Thomas Indicted
events.description: A federal grand jury indicted Tova Noel and Michael Thomas on charges of conspiracy and falsification of records related to inmate counts and rounds.

events.title: Deferred Prosecution Agreements
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office entered into deferred prosecution agreements with Noel and Thomas, requiring community service and interviews.

events.title: Charges Dismissed
events.description: After successfully fulfilling their deferred prosecution agreements, all charges against Noel and Thomas were dismissed.

keyFacts: The OIG investigation found numerous and serious failures by MCC New York staff, including falsification of records, failure to assign Epstein a cellmate as required, failure to conduct inmate counts and rounds, and allowing an unmonitored phone call.
Epstein was left alone and unmonitored in his cell from approximately 10:40 p.m. on August 9 until he was found hanged at about 6:30 a.m. on August 10, 2019.
The OIG did not uncover evidence contradicting the FBI's determination that Epstein's death was a suicide, and the Medical Examiner's autopsy findings were consistent with suicide by hanging.
Two MCC New York employees, Tova Noel and Michael Thomas, were criminally charged for falsifying records; they entered deferred prosecution agreements and the charges were later dismissed.

A critical security camera system failure at MCC New York, which began on July 29, 2019, was not discovered until August 8 and not repaired until after Epstein's death, resulting in limited recorded video evidence.
The OIG report found that BOP employees failed to ensure Jeffrey Epstein continuously had a cellmate, as recommended by Psychology Department personnel, prior to his death.
The BOP concurred with all eight OIG recommendations aimed at reforming suicide watch procedures, cellmate assignments, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security systems.
The report reveals the BOP had already updated its suicide watch and psychological observation processes in the years since Epstein's death, implementing a more individualized approach.
The OIG analysis indicates the BOP's response to Recommendation 2 (ensuring high-risk inmates keep a cellmate) was 'not fully responsive,' requiring further procedural development.
The document is an official OIG draft report dated June 22, 2023, focusing on systemic failures within the BOP rather than naming individual staff members involved in the incident.
